section_title: Cohabitation caused by deceitful belief of lawful marriage
full_text: Every man who by deceit causes any woman who is not lawfully married to him to believe that she is lawfully married to him and to cohabit or have sexual intercourse with him in that belief, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to ten years, and shall also be liable to fine.
layman_explanation: This section applies when a man deceives a woman into believing she is legally married to him and lives with or has sexual relations with her based on that false belief. It protects women from fraudulent marital relationships.

section_title: Marrying again during lifetime of husband or wife
full_text: Whoever, having a husband or wife living, marries again during the life of such spouse, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to seven years, and shall also be liable to fine.
layman_explanation: This section deals with bigamy. It applies when a person marries again while their lawful spouse is still alive, except in specific legal exceptions such as a spouse being missing for seven years.
embedding_text: IPC 494 bigamy second marriage punishment explanation

section_title: Same offence with concealment of former marriage
full_text: Whoever commits the offence of bigamy having concealed from the person with whom the subsequent marriage is contracted the fact of the former marriage shall be punished with imprisonment which may extend to ten years and fine.
layman_explanation: This section applies when a person commits bigamy and hides the fact of their previous marriage from the new spouse, making the offence more serious due to deliberate concealment.
embedding_text: IPC 495 concealment of previous marriage explanation

section_title: Marriage ceremony fraudulently gone through without lawful marriage
full_text: Whoever dishonestly or fraudulently goes through a marriage ceremony knowing that it does not result in a lawful marriage shall be punished with imprisonment which may extend to seven years and fine.
layman_explanation: This section punishes fake or sham marriage ceremonies performed with fraudulent intent, where the person knows the marriage is not legally valid.

full_text: Whoever has sexual intercourse with the wife of another man without the consent or connivance of that man shall be punished with imprisonment which may extend to five years or with fine or with both.
layman_explanation: This section earlier criminalized adultery by a man with another man's wife. Note: This section has been struck down by the Supreme Court and is no longer in force.

section_title: Enticing or detaining a married woman with criminal intent
full_text: Whoever takes or entices away or detains a married woman with intent that she may have illicit intercourse shall be punished with imprisonment which may extend to two years or fine or both.
layman_explanation: This section applies when a person unlawfully takes, entices, or keeps a married woman with the intention of illicit sexual relations.

chapter_name: Public Health Safety Decency and Morals
full_text: A person is guilty of a public nuisance who does any act or illegal omission which causes common injury, danger or annoyance to the public. A common nuisance is not excused on the ground that it causes some convenience or advantage.
layman_explanation: This section defines public nuisance. It applies when an act or neglect causes harm, danger or inconvenience to the public at large, even if it benefits some people.

chapter_name: Public Health Safety Decency and Morals
section_title: Adulteration of food or drink intended for sale
full_text: Whoever adulterates any article of food or drink so as to make it noxious, intending to sell it or knowing it is likely to be sold, shall be punished with imprisonment up to six months or fine or both.
layman_explanation: This section applies when food or drink is deliberately adulterated and made harmful for human consumption with the intention of selling it.

chapter_name: Public Health Safety Decency and Morals
section_title: Sale of noxious food or drink
full_text: Whoever sells or offers for sale any food or drink which is noxious or unfit for consumption, knowing it to be harmful, shall be punished with imprisonment up to six months or fine or both.
layman_explanation: This section punishes selling or offering harmful or spoiled food or drinks that are unsafe for human consumption.
embedding_text: IPC 273 sale of harmful food explanation

chapter_name: Public Health Safety Decency and Morals
full_text: Whoever adulterates any drug or medical preparation to reduce its effectiveness or make it harmful, intending that it be sold or used for medical purposes, shall be punished with imprisonment up to six months or fine or both.
layman_explanation: This section applies when medicines or drugs are adulterated in a way that reduces their effectiveness or makes them dangerous.

chapter_name: Public Health Safety Decency and Morals
full_text: Whoever knowingly sells or distributes adulterated drugs or medical preparations as genuine shall be punished with imprisonment up to six months or fine or both.
layman_explanation: This section punishes selling or supplying medicines that are known to be adulterated, risking public health.
embedding_text: IPC 275 sale of adulterated drugs explanation

chapter_name: Public Health Safety Decency and Morals
section_title: Rash driving or riding on a public way
full_text: Whoever drives any vehicle in a rash or negligent manner on a public way so as to endanger human life shall be punished with imprisonment up to six months or fine or both.
layman_explanation: This section applies to rash or negligent driving on public roads that endangers human life or safety.

chapter_name: Public Health Safety Decency and Morals
section_title: Negligent conduct with respect to animal
full_text: Whoever knowingly or negligently fails to control any animal in his possession so as to prevent danger to human life shall be punished with imprisonment up to six months or fine or both.
layman_explanation: This section applies when a person fails to control an animal properly, leading to danger or injury to others.
embedding_text: IPC 289 negligent conduct with animal explanation

chapter_name: Public Health Safety Decency and Morals
full_text: Whoever commits a public nuisance in cases not otherwise punishable shall be punished with fine which may extend to two hundred rupees.
layman_explanation: This section provides punishment for public nuisance where no specific punishment is mentioned elsewhere in the IPC.
embedding_text: IPC 290 punishment for public nuisance explanation

chapter_name: Public Health Safety Decency and Morals
section_title: Sale of obscene books and objects
full_text: Whoever sells, distributes, exhibits, imports or circulates obscene books, drawings or objects shall be punished on first conviction with imprisonment up to two years and fine, and on subsequent conviction up to five years and fine.
layman_explanation: This section criminalizes the sale, distribution or circulation of obscene materials that may corrupt public morals, with exceptions for art, religion and education.

chapter_name: Public Health Safety Decency and Morals
full_text: Whoever does any obscene act or sings obscene songs in or near a public place causing annoyance shall be punished with imprisonment up to three months or fine or both.
layman_explanation: This section applies to obscene behavior or language in public places that causes annoyance to others.
embedding_text: IPC 294 obscene acts in public explanation

section_title: Injuring or defiling place of worship
full_text: Whoever destroys, damages or defiles any place of worship or any object held sacred with the intention of insulting the religion of any class shall be punished with imprisonment up to two years or fine or both.
layman_explanation: This section applies when someone intentionally damages or defiles a place of worship or sacred object to insult the religion of a particular community.
embedding_text: IPC 295 defiling place of worship explanation

section_title: Deliberate and malicious acts intended to outrage religious feelings
full_text: Whoever deliberately and maliciously insults the religion or religious beliefs of any class by words, signs or representations shall be punished with imprisonment up to three years or fine or both.
layman_explanation: This section deals with intentional and malicious acts such as speech, writing or representations meant to outrage the religious feelings of a community.

full_text: Whoever voluntarily causes disturbance to any religious assembly lawfully engaged in worship or ceremonies shall be punished with imprisonment up to one year or fine or both.
layman_explanation: This section applies when a person intentionally disturbs a religious gathering or ceremony that is being lawfully conducted.

section_title: Trespassing on burial places or places of worship
full_text: Whoever trespasses on burial places or places of worship or offers indignity to a human corpse with intent to insult religion or wound feelings shall be punished with imprisonment up to one year or fine or both.
layman_explanation: This section applies when someone trespasses on burial grounds or funeral places, or disrespects a corpse, with intent to insult religion or hurt sentiments.

section_title: Uttering words with deliberate intent to wound religious feelings
full_text: Whoever deliberately utters words, makes sounds, gestures or places objects with intent to wound the religious feelings of any person shall be punished with imprisonment up to one year or fine or both.
layman_explanation: This section applies when a person intentionally uses words, gestures or actions to hurt the religious feelings of another individual.

full_text: Culpable homicide is murder when death is caused with intention or knowledge that the act is likely to cause death, subject to specific exceptions.
layman_explanation: This section defines murder. It applies when a person intentionally causes death or commits an act knowing it will almost certainly cause death, except in legally defined exceptional circumstances.

full_text: Whoever commits murder shall be punished with death or imprisonment for life and fine.
layman_explanation: This section prescribes punishment for murder, including death penalty or life imprisonment.

full_text: Whoever causes death by rash or negligent act not amounting to culpable homicide shall be punished with imprisonment up to two years or fine or both.
layman_explanation: This section applies when death occurs due to negligence, such as reckless driving, without intention to kill.

full_text: Death of a woman within seven years of marriage due to cruelty or harassment for dowry is deemed dowry death.
layman_explanation: This section deals with dowry-related deaths and presumes the husband or relatives responsible.

section_title: Abetment of suicide of child or insane person
full_text: Abetting suicide of a minor, insane or intoxicated person is punishable with death, life imprisonment or imprisonment up to ten years.
layman_explanation: This section applies when vulnerable persons are driven to suicide by another person.

full_text: Whoever does any act with intention or knowledge to cause death shall be punished with imprisonment up to ten years or life imprisonment if hurt is caused.
layman_explanation: This section applies when an attempt is made to kill, even if death does not occur.

full_text: A person habitually associated for committing robbery or murder is a thug.
layman_explanation: This section defines the offence of being part of a criminal gang involved in murder or robbery.

full_text: Whoever is a thug shall be punished with imprisonment for life and fine.
layman_explanation: This section prescribes punishment for the offence of thug.

full_text: Causing miscarriage without good faith to save woman’s life is punishable.
layman_explanation: This section criminalizes unlawful abortion.

full_text: Causing miscarriage without consent is punishable with life imprisonment or imprisonment up to ten years.
layman_explanation: This section deals with forced abortion.

full_text: Causing permanent or partial damage by acid attack is punishable with minimum ten years imprisonment or life.
layman_explanation: This section deals with acid attacks causing severe bodily harm.

full_text: Attempt to throw acid with intent to cause harm is punishable.
layman_explanation: This section applies even when acid attack is attempted but harm is not fully caused.

section_title: Grievous hurt to deter public servant
full_text: Voluntarily causing grievous hurt to deter a public servant is punishable with imprisonment up to ten years.
layman_explanation: This section protects public servants performing official duties.
embedding_text: IPC 333 grievous hurt to public servant explanation

full_text: Wrongfully restraining a person is punishable with simple imprisonment or fine.
layman_explanation: This section applies when a person is unlawfully prevented from moving freely.

full_text: Wrongfully confining a person is punishable with imprisonment up to one year.
layman_explanation: This section applies when a person is unlawfully confined.

full_text: Assault or criminal force with intent to outrage modesty is punishable.
layman_explanation: This section protects women from sexual assault and inappropriate physical force.

full_text: Sexual harassment includes unwelcome physical contact, sexual remarks or demands.
layman_explanation: This section criminalizes sexual harassment of women.

full_text: Repeatedly following or contacting a woman against her will is stalking.
layman_explanation: This section addresses physical and online stalking.

full_text: Kidnapping from India or lawful guardianship is punishable.
layman_explanation: This section criminalizes kidnapping.

full_text: Kidnapping for ransom is punishable with death or life imprisonment.
layman_explanation: This section deals with kidnapping involving ransom demands.

full_text: Rape is punishable with rigorous imprisonment not less than ten years and may extend to life or death in aggravated cases.
layman_explanation: This section prescribes punishment for rape and its aggravated forms.

full_text: Carnal intercourse against the order of nature is punishable.
layman_explanation: This section is partly decriminalized; consensual acts between adults are no longer offences.

full_text: Whoever threatens another with injury to person, reputation or property with intent to cause alarm or compel action commits criminal intimidation.
layman_explanation: This section defines criminal intimidation. It applies when someone threatens another person to create fear or force them to act against their legal rights.

section_title: Intentional insult with intent to provoke breach of peace
full_text: Whoever intentionally insults another knowing it is likely to provoke breach of peace shall be punished.
layman_explanation: This section applies when abusive or insulting words are used deliberately to provoke violence or disturb public peace.
embedding_text: IPC 504 intentional insult breach of peace explanation

full_text: Whoever makes or circulates statements or rumours causing public fear, enmity or incitement to offences shall be punished.
layman_explanation: This section applies to spreading rumours or statements that cause public panic, communal hatred or encourage offences against the State or public order.
embedding_text: IPC 505 statements causing public mischief explanation

full_text: Whoever commits criminal intimidation shall be punished, and if threat involves death, grievous hurt or serious offence, punishment is enhanced.
layman_explanation: This section provides punishment for criminal intimidation, with harsher punishment for serious threats.
embedding_text: IPC 506 punishment for criminal intimidation explanation

full_text: Criminal intimidation committed anonymously or by concealing identity is punishable in addition to Section 506.
layman_explanation: This section applies when threats are made anonymously or while hiding the offender’s identity.

section_title: Act caused by inducing belief of divine displeasure
full_text: Whoever induces a person to act or omit action by threatening divine displeasure shall be punished.
layman_explanation: This section applies when religious fear or superstition is used to force someone to act against their legal rights.

full_text: Whoever utters words, gestures or intrudes upon privacy with intent to insult a woman’s modesty shall be punished.
layman_explanation: This section protects women from verbal, gestural or privacy-invading harassment.
embedding_text: IPC 509 insulting modesty of woman explanation

section_title: Misconduct in public by a drunken person
full_text: Whoever appears intoxicated in public and causes annoyance shall be punished.
layman_explanation: This section applies when a drunk person behaves in a disorderly or annoying manner in public.
embedding_text: IPC 510 drunken misconduct in public explanation

full_text: Whoever makes or publishes any imputation concerning any person intending to harm, or knowing it will harm, that person’s reputation commits defamation, subject to statutory exceptions.
layman_explanation: This section defines defamation. It applies when false statements, words, signs or representations harm a person’s reputation, except in legally protected situations like truth for public good or good-faith opinions.

full_text: Whoever defames another shall be punished with simple imprisonment up to two years or with fine or with both.
layman_explanation: This section prescribes punishment for committing defamation under Section 499.

full_text: Whoever prints or engraves any matter knowing it to be defamatory shall be punished with simple imprisonment up to two years or fine or both.
layman_explanation: This section applies when defamatory content is printed or engraved knowingly, such as newspapers or posters.

full_text: Whoever sells or offers for sale any printed or engraved substance knowing it contains defamatory matter shall be punished with simple imprisonment up to two years or fine or both.
layman_explanation: This section applies to selling or distributing defamatory material with knowledge of its nature.
embedding_text: IPC 502 sale of defamatory material explanation

chapter_name: Cruelty by Husband or Relatives of Husband
section_title: Husband or relative of husband subjecting woman to cruelty
full_text: Whoever, being the husband or relative of the husband of a woman, subjects such woman to cruelty shall be punished with imprisonment up to three years and fine.
layman_explanation: This section applies when a husband or his relatives subject a married woman to physical or mental cruelty, including harassment for dowry or conduct that may drive her to suicide or cause serious harm.
embedding_text: IPC 498A cruelty by husband or relatives explanation

section_title: Punishment for attempting to commit offences
full_text: Whoever attempts to commit an offence punishable with imprisonment for life or other imprisonment, and does any act towards its commission, shall be punished where no specific punishment is provided.
layman_explanation: This section applies when a person makes an attempt to commit a crime but fails to complete it. Even if the offence is not completed, doing an act towards committing it is punishable.
punishment_summary: Up to Half of Original Punishment
embedding_text: IPC 511 attempt to commit offence explanation

full_text: Whoever makes a false document or electronic record with intent to cause damage, injury or fraud commits forgery.
layman_explanation: This section defines forgery. It applies when someone creates a fake document or electronic record to deceive or cause harm.

full_text: A person is said to make a false document when he dishonestly makes, alters or causes execution of a document or electronic record.
layman_explanation: This section explains what amounts to making a false document, including signing, altering or misusing documents fraudulently.

full_text: Whoever commits forgery shall be punished with imprisonment up to two years or fine or both.
layman_explanation: This section provides punishment for basic forgery offences.

section_title: Forgery of court records or public registers
full_text: Forgery of court records, public registers or official documents is punishable with imprisonment up to seven years and fine.
layman_explanation: This section deals with forging official or court-related documents, which is treated more seriously.
embedding_text: IPC 466 forgery of public records explanation

section_title: Forgery of valuable security or will
full_text: Forgery of valuable securities, wills or authority documents is punishable with life imprisonment or imprisonment up to ten years and fine.
layman_explanation: This section covers very serious forgery involving wills, securities or financial authority documents.
embedding_text: IPC 467 forgery of will or security explanation

full_text: Forgery committed with intent to cheat is punishable with imprisonment up to seven years and fine.
layman_explanation: This section applies when forged documents are used specifically to cheat someone.

full_text: A forged document is a false document or electronic record made by forgery.
layman_explanation: This section defines what constitutes a forged document.

full_text: Whoever uses a forged document as genuine knowing it to be forged shall be punished as if he forged it.
layman_explanation: This section punishes using fake documents even if the person did not create them.

full_text: Whoever counterfeits currency notes or bank notes shall be punished with life imprisonment or imprisonment up to ten years and fine.
layman_explanation: This section deals with making fake currency or bank notes.

full_text: Whoever uses or traffics forged or counterfeit currency knowing it to be fake shall be punished with life imprisonment or imprisonment up to ten years and fine.
layman_explanation: This section applies to circulation or use of fake currency.

full_text: Possession of counterfeit currency with intent to use it as genuine is punishable.
layman_explanation: This section applies when someone knowingly keeps fake currency for use.
embedding_text: IPC 489C possession of counterfeit currency explanation

section_title: Making or possessing tools for counterfeiting
full_text: Whoever makes or possesses machinery or materials for counterfeiting currency shall be punished.
layman_explanation: This section targets preparation and tools used for printing fake currency.

section_title: Making or using documents resembling currency
full_text: Whoever makes or uses documents resembling currency notes shall be punished with fine.
layman_explanation: This section applies to fake notes or documents resembling currency even if not fully counterfeit.

full_text: Whoever dishonestly takes movable property out of another’s possession without consent commits theft.
layman_explanation: This section defines theft. It applies when movable property is taken dishonestly without the owner’s consent.

full_text: Whoever commits theft shall be punished with imprisonment up to three years or fine or both.
layman_explanation: This section prescribes punishment for theft.

full_text: Whoever forcibly or suddenly takes movable property from a person commits snatching.
layman_explanation: This section defines snatching as a form of theft involving force or sudden seizure.

full_text: Punishment for snatching includes imprisonment from five to ten years and fine.
layman_explanation: This section provides enhanced punishment for snatching, especially if hurt is caused.

full_text: Whoever commits dacoity shall be punished with life imprisonment or rigorous imprisonment up to ten years and fine.
layman_explanation: This section applies to robbery committed by five or more persons.

full_text: If murder is committed during dacoity, all participants are liable.
layman_explanation: This section applies when murder occurs during dacoity.

full_text: Receiving or retaining stolen property knowing it to be stolen is punishable.
layman_explanation: This section applies to people who knowingly receive stolen goods.

full_text: Helping conceal or dispose of stolen property is punishable.
layman_explanation: This section punishes assistance in hiding or selling stolen property.
embedding_text: IPC 414 assisting concealment of stolen property explanation

full_text: Whoever cheats shall be punished with imprisonment up to one year or fine or both.
layman_explanation: This section provides punishment for cheating.

full_text: Whoever causes destruction or damage to property with intent to cause wrongful loss commits mischief.
layman_explanation: This section defines mischief involving damage or destruction of property.

full_text: Punishment for mischief includes imprisonment up to three months or fine or both.
layman_explanation: This section prescribes punishment for basic mischief.

section_title: Mischief causing damage of fifty rupees
full_text: Mischief causing loss of fifty rupees or more is punishable.
layman_explanation: This section applies when mischief causes significant monetary loss.

section_title: Mischief by killing or maiming animal
full_text: Killing or maiming animals of value is punishable.
layman_explanation: This section protects animals from intentional harm.

section_title: Mischief by killing cattle or valuable animals
full_text: Killing or maiming cattle or valuable animals is punishable with imprisonment up to five years.
layman_explanation: This section applies to serious harm to cattle or valuable animals.

full_text: Mischief by fire or explosive causing property damage is punishable.
layman_explanation: This section applies to arson causing significant damage.

full_text: Mischief by fire destroying a house or place of worship is punishable with life imprisonment.
layman_explanation: This section covers arson of houses or religious buildings.

chapter_name: False Evidence and Offences Against Public Justice
full_text: Whoever, being legally bound to state the truth, makes a false statement which he knows or believes to be false is said to give false evidence.
layman_explanation: This section applies when a person lies under oath or makes a false declaration while legally bound to tell the truth.

chapter_name: False Evidence and Offences Against Public Justice
full_text: Whoever creates false circumstances, records or documents intending them to be used as evidence to mislead judicial or legal proceedings commits fabrication of false evidence.
layman_explanation: This section applies when someone creates fake evidence or records to mislead courts or public authorities.

chapter_name: False Evidence and Offences Against Public Justice
full_text: Giving or fabricating false evidence in judicial proceedings is punishable with imprisonment up to seven years; otherwise up to three years.
layman_explanation: This section provides punishment for perjury and fabrication of evidence, with higher punishment for judicial proceedings.
embedding_text: IPC 193 punishment for false evidence explanation

chapter_name: False Evidence and Offences Against Public Justice
full_text: Whoever issues or signs a certificate knowing it to be false shall be punished as if he gave false evidence.
layman_explanation: This section applies when a false certificate is knowingly issued or signed for legal use.

chapter_name: False Evidence and Offences Against Public Justice
section_title: Using as true a certificate known to be false
full_text: Whoever uses a certificate knowing it to be false shall be punished as if he gave false evidence.
layman_explanation: This section applies to using fake certificates in legal or official matters.

section_title: Definitions of candidate and electoral right
full_text: This section defines the terms candidate and electoral right for the purposes of election offences.
layman_explanation: This section only defines who is a candidate and what electoral rights mean in elections.

full_text: Giving or accepting gratification to influence the exercise of any electoral right constitutes bribery.
layman_explanation: This section applies when money, gifts or benefits are given or taken to influence voting or candidature.

full_text: Voluntarily interfering with the free exercise of electoral rights is undue influence.
layman_explanation: This section applies when threats, religious pressure or coercion are used to influence voters or candidates.

full_text: Voting in the name of another person or multiple voting constitutes personation.
layman_explanation: This section applies when someone votes fraudulently or impersonates another voter.

full_text: Bribery at elections is punishable with imprisonment up to one year or fine or both.
layman_explanation: This section prescribes punishment for election bribery; treating is punishable with fine only.
embedding_text: IPC 171E punishment for election bribery explanation

section_title: Punishment for undue influence or personation
full_text: Undue influence or personation at elections is punishable with imprisonment up to one year or fine or both.
layman_explanation: This section provides punishment for coercion or impersonation during elections.
embedding_text: IPC 171F punishment undue influence personation explanation

section_title: False statement in connection with election
full_text: Making false statements about a candidate’s personal character to affect election results is punishable with fine.
layman_explanation: This section applies to spreading false information or fake news about candidates during elections.

section_title: Illegal payments in connection with election
full_text: Unauthorized election expenses for promoting a candidate are punishable with fine.
layman_explanation: This section regulates election spending and punishes unauthorized campaign expenses.

full_text: Failure to maintain proper election expense accounts is punishable.
layman_explanation: This section applies when a candidate fails to keep or submit election expense accounts as required.
embedding_text: IPC 171I failure to keep election accounts explanation

full_text: An assembly of five or more persons with a common object to commit an offence or disturb public peace is called an unlawful assembly.
layman_explanation: This section defines unlawful assembly. It applies when five or more people gather with an illegal or violent common purpose.

full_text: Whenever force or violence is used by an unlawful assembly in pursuit of its common object, every member is guilty of rioting.
layman_explanation: This section defines rioting. It applies when an unlawful assembly uses violence or force.

full_text: Whoever is guilty of rioting shall be punished with imprisonment up to two years or fine or both.
layman_explanation: This section prescribes punishment for the offence of rioting.
